questions.text: Transparency of corneal endothelium is maintained by: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratan sulphate

 

  • Keratan sulfate is a key glycosaminoglycan present in the corneal endothelium. It plays a significant role in maintaining corneal transparency by regulating hydration, contributing to the structural integrity of the cornea, and preventing swelling, which could impair vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparan sulfate: Heparan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in the cornea, but its main role is in the basement membrane and Bowman's membrane, rather than the corneal endothelium. It plays a role in supporting the structure but is not the primary factor for endothelial transparency.

 

Option C. Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another glycosaminoglycan found in the cornea, but its primary role is not related to endothelial transparency. It contributes to the overall structure and function of the cornea but does not play a direct role in maintaining endothelial clarity.

 

Option D. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid is essential for regulating hydration within the cornea, but its main role is in the corneal stroma, not the endothelium. It ensures the cornea remains transparent by preventing excessive swelling in the stromal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 602

choices.text: Nelson syndrome
Sheehan syndrome
Conn's syndrome

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

 

Explanation:  

 

Nelson syndrome occurs in patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the adrenalectomy, the absence of cortisol feedback leads to increased secretion of ACTH by the pituitary adenoma. This results in:

 

  • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes.
  • Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: Caused by postpartum necrosis of the pituitary gland, leading to hypopituitarism. It presents with failure to lactate, amenorrhea, and hypothyroidism, but not with hyperpigmentation or vision deficits post-adrenalectomy.

 

Option C. Conn's syndrome: Primary hyperaldosteronism, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause hyperpigmentation or vision deficits.

 

Option D. Addison's disease:  Primary adrenal insufficiency presenting with hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH, but it is not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and vision deficits following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, due to the growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with deterioration of vision 3 weeks after cataract extraction and intraocular lens (IOL) implantation. Slit-lamp examination reveals honeycomb maculopathy, and fluorescein angiography shows ‘flower petal’ hyperfluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cystoid Macular Edema

 

This patient presents with classic features of Cystoid Macular Edema (CME), particularly the Irvine-Gass syndrome, which is CME occurring after cataract surgery. The key diagnostic elements are: 

 

  • Deterioration of vision after cataract surgery (a common timing for CME)
  • Honeycomb appearance of macula on slit-lamp examination
  • The pathognomonic "flower petal" pattern on fluorescein angiography, which represents leakage and accumulation of dye in the macular region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age-Related Macular Degeneration (ARMD): This is incorrect as ARMD typically presents with drusen, pigmentary changes, or choroidal neovascularization. It does not show the classic "flower petal" pattern on fluorescein angiography and is not specifically related to recent cataract surgery.

 

Option B. Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR): This is incorrect as CSR typically affects younger patients, especially males with type A personality. On fluorescein angiography, CSR shows either "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" patterns of hyperfluorescence, not the flower petal appearance.

 

Option C. Macular Dystrophy: This is incorrect as macular dystrophies are genetic disorders with gradual onset, not suddenly appearing after cataract surgery. They also don't typically present with the honeycomb appearance or flower petal pattern on fluorescein angiography.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cystoid Macular Edema is a common complication after cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), characterized by honeycomb appearance on clinical examination and flower petal pattern on fluorescein angiography due to leakage from macular capillaries.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusion. Her HRCT shows a "tree-in-bud" pattern, indicating lung consolidation and effusion. Analysis of pleural fluid reveals high adenosine deaminase (ADA) levels with a predominance of lymphocytes. What is the most likely finding on lymph node biopsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing epithelioid granuloma

 

This is a classic presentation of tuberculosis (TB):

 

  • "Tree-in-bud" appearance on HRCT indicates endobronchial spread — a hallmark of active pulmonary TB.
  • Mediastinal lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion with lymphocyte predominance further support a tuberculous etiology.
  • High ADA (>40 U/L) in pleural fluid is a strong indicator of TB pleuritis.

 

The most characteristic lymph node biopsy finding in TB is:

 

  • Necrotizing (caseating) epithelioid granulomas
  •  Composed of epithelioid cells (from activated macrophages), Langhans giant cells, and central caseous necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal hyphae surrounded by lymphocytes:  Seen in invasive fungal infections (e.g., aspergillosis, histoplasmosis), more common in immunocompromised individuals; not typically associated with high ADA.

 

Option B. Anthracosis pigment: Black carbon pigment in lungs/lymph nodes from pollution or smoking. Not pathological in itself and doesn’t cause systemic symptoms or effusion.

 

Option D. Reactive hyperplasia: Seen in viral or nonspecific bacterial infections. No granulomas or caseation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young woman with systemic symptoms, tree-in-bud pattern, lymphocytic pleural effusion, and high ADA, TB is the most likely diagnosis. The hallmark histopathological finding is a necrotizing epithelioid granuloma.

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry
Complete blood count (CBC)

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred diagnostic tool for screening metabolic diseases, particularly inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), in children. This technology allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple metabolic disorders by measuring the levels of various metabolites in a single blood sample.

 

The high sensitivity and specificity of tandem mass spectrometry make it an ideal choice for newborn screening programs. It can detect a wide range of metabolic disorders early, enabling prompt intervention that can prevent severe complications and improve long-term outcomes. The method works by ionizing chemical compounds and then analyzing the ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio, which allows for precise identification and quantification of different substances in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete blood count (CBC): CBC is a basic test that measures different components of the blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. While it provides essential information about overall health and can help diagnose various conditions, it is not specific or sensitive enough for screening metabolic diseases.

 

Option C. Urinalysis: Urinalysis is a common test that examines the content of urine. It can help detect some metabolic disorders but is not as comprehensive or effective as tandem mass spectrometry for screening a wide range of metabolic diseases.

 

Option D. Genetic testing: Genetic testing is used to identify specific genetic mutations that may cause metabolic disorders. While it can confirm a diagnosis, it is not typically used as the primary screening tool due to its complexity and the time required for analysis. Genetic testing is more often used after an initial screening suggests the presence of a metabolic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children due to its ability to detect multiple metabolic disorders from a single blood sample.

questions.text: What is the recommended daily allowance (RDA) for a woman engaged in heavy work? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 2800 kcal/day

 

The energy requirement for an adult woman engaged in heavy work is 2,850 kcal/day as established in the 2010 dietary guidelines. This is based on a reference woman weighing 55 kg, with heavy work requiring approximately 52 kcal/kg/day. 2800 kcal/day is the closest match to this recommendation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2300 kcal/day: This value is significantly lower than required for heavy work. It falls between the energy requirements for sedentary work (1,900 kcal/day) and moderate work (2,230 kcal/day) for adult women.

 

Option B. 2600 kcal/day: This is insufficient for heavy work, though it exceeds the requirement for moderate work. Heavy physical activity demands substantially more energy than this amount provides.

 

Option D. 3800 kcal/day: This greatly exceeds the recommended allowance for women engaged in heavy work (2,850 kcal/day). Even for men performing heavy work, the requirement is 3,490 kcal/day, making this value excessively high.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Energy requirements are specifically tailored to gender, body weight, and physical activity level, with heavy work requiring substantially more calories than sedentary or moderate work activities.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not given during pregnancy? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles

 

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated during pregnancy because it is a live attenuated vaccine. 
  • Pregnancy is considered an immunocompromised state, and live vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy except for Yellow Fever vaccine. 
  • Administration of measles vaccine during pregnancy could theoretically pose a risk to the developing fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus Toxoid: Tetanus Toxoid is routinely administered during pregnancy. It's included in the standard antenatal care protocol with TT-1 given early in pregnancy and TT-2 given four weeks later, or a booster dose if the woman received TT doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years.

 

Option C. HBV (Hepatitis B): Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a live vaccine. It can be safely administered during pregnancy when indicated and poses no theoretical risk to the fetus.

 

Option D. Rabies: Rabies vaccine is a killed/inactivated vaccine. It can be administered during pregnancy in post-exposure situations without risk to the fetus. As it's not a live vaccine, it doesn't carry the theoretical risks that contraindicate live vaccines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live attenuated vaccines are generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to theoretical risk of fetal infection, while killed/inactivated vaccines, toxoids, and recombinant vaccines can be administered during pregnancy when indicated.

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib
Attached with transverse process of C7

questions.text: Which among the following statement is incorrect regarding Sibson’s fascia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

 

Sibson's fascia is joined to the first rib's inner border, not the second rib.

 

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane)

 

  • Covers the apical portion of the lung and acts as a dividing line between the lower neck and the thorax.
  • It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.
  • It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles.
  • The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

 

Clinical significance

 

  • The suprapleural membrane's function is to protect the apex of the lung (the part that extends outside the rib cage) and the cervical fascia. This aids in resisting intrathoracic pressure changes, preventing neck inflation and deflation during expiration and inspiration, and also providing rigidity to the thoracic inlet.
  • Herniation of the cervical fascia may result due to injury to suprapleural membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Covers apical part of lung (Correct): Sibson's fascia covers the apical (uppermost) part of the lung and helps separate the cervical pleura from the surrounding structures.

 

Option C. Attached with transverse process of C7 (Correct): Sibson's fascia is posteriorly attached with the tip of the transverse process of C7.

 

Option D. Vessels pass above the fascia (Correct): Blood vessels, including the subclavian vessels, pass above Sibson's fascia as they enter and exit the thoracic cavity. This fascia serves as a landmark for the placement of central venous catheters, as it delineates the boundary between the cervical and thoracic regions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sibson's fascia is not directly attached to the inner border of the 2nd rib. Instead, it is associated with the cervical pleura and extends superiorly to attach to the transverse process of the 7th cervical (C7) vertebra. It forms the outer boundary of the cervicothoracic (suprapleural) space.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) t (9:22)

 

Massive splenomegaly and a peripheral smear showing leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils are symptoms of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This condition is characterized by a translocation between t (9;22).

 

CML is classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by a translocation between BCR (on chromosome 22) and ABL (on chromosome 9) to form a fusion gene. It leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is characteristic of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. t (8;22): Associated with Burkitt lymphoma involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8.

 

Option C. t (15;17): Associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), involving the PML and RARA genes.

 

Option D. t (8;14): Also associated with Burkitt lymphoma, involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.

choices.text: Hemophilia A
Hemophilia B
Von Willebrand disease

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is characterized by prolonged bleeding time due to a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a critical protein in platelet adhesion and aggregation processes. Prolonged APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) is also seen in this condition because VWF stabilizes factor VIII, an essential clotting factor. The deficiency or dysfunction of VWF thus impacts both primary hemostasis (bleeding time) and secondary hemostasis (APTT).

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Hemophilia A and B. Hemophilia B: These conditions involve deficiencies in clotting factors VIII and IX, respectively, which primarily affect the intrinsic coagulation pathway but not typically the bleeding time.

 

Option D. Hemophilia C: Known as a deficiency in factor XI, this condition also typically affects the intrinsic pathway and APTT but not bleeding time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolonged bleeding time and prolonged APTT is seen in Von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs in leprosy treatment cause hyperpigmentation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used primarily in the treatment of leprosy.
  • One of the notable side effects of clofazimine is skin pigmentation changes, which can manifest as hyperpigmentation.
  • This occurs because clofazimine accumulates in the skin, leading to discoloration.
  • The pigmentation typically appears as a reddish or brownish coloration and can be distressing for patients due to its noticeable cosmetic impact.
  • The pigmentation is long-lasting and may take several months to years to fade after discontinuation of the drug.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is another drug used in the treatment of leprosy, but it does not cause hyperpigmentation. Its side effects include hemolysis and methemoglobinemia, especially in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, including leprosy, but it is not associated with hyperpigmentation. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendonitis.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is an antibiotic used to treat several bacterial infections, including leprosy. It can cause reddish-orange discoloration of bodily fluids like urine, sweat, and tears but does not cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clofazimine is a drug used in leprosy treatment that can cause significant and long-lasting hyperpigmentation of the skin.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acanthosis nigricans

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is the illness depicted in the image.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pityriasis rotunda

 

  • Description: This is a rare skin condition characterized by large, round patches of dry, scaly skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Melasma

 

  • Description: Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches, mainly on the face (cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip). It's often called the "mask of pregnancy."

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis

 

  • Description: An inflammatory muscle disease, dermatomyositis presents with skin rash and muscle weakness. The rash is often reddish or purple, seen on the eyelids, knuckles, elbows, knees, and sometimes the chest and back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 147, Page nos 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology 3rd edition Page no 391

choices.text: Rupture of valve
Calcification and fibrosis
Hypertrophy of ventricular wall
Hypertrophy of the atrial wall

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcification and Fibrosis

 

The illustration depicts rheumatic heart disease and mitral stenosis with a fish mouth or buttonhole appearance. Calcification and fibrosis are the causes.

 

RHD is primarily identified by mitral stenosis, for which it is essentially the primary cause, and deforming fibrotic valvular disease.

 

The leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusing of the tendinous cords are the three primary anatomic alterations of the mitral valve in chronic RHD.

 

"Fish mouth" or "buttonhole" stenosis are caused by calcification and fibrous bridging over the valvular commissures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture of valve: Not indicated in the image or history provided.

 

Option C. Hypertrophy of ventricular wall: While ventricular wall hypertrophy may occur due to increased workload from valvular heart disease, it is not visible on this image of the valve.

 

Option D. Hypertrophy of the atrial wall: Similar to ventricular hypertrophy, atrial wall hypertrophy may occur in response to increased pressure from stenosed valves but is not the direct cause visible in the valve image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease, the mitral valve often undergoes significant morphological changes due to fibrosis and calcification, leading to stenosis with a characteristic "fish mouth" appearance. Understanding these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the progression of the disease.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which embryonic pharyngeal arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 6th arch

 

The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.

 

  • During embryonic development, the aortic arches give rise to several structures in the neck and chest.
  • The 6th arch artery, which is present on both the right and left sides, gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus.
  • As the arch arteries regress and are replaced by the adult structures, the recurrent laryngeal nerves, which innervate the muscles of the larynx, become trapped behind the great vessels.
  • The distal 6th arch artery vanishes on the right side. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under the 4th arch artery, which becomes the future right subclavian artery, because there is no 5th arch artery.
  • On the left side, the 6th arch artery persists, which develops into ductus arteriosus, which later forms ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under it and therefore, has a relatively long course.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch on its way to the larynx.
  • In the case of the long left recurrent laryngeal nerve, the nerve passes inferior to the ligamentum arteriosum, which is a remnant of the ductus arteriosus that is derived from the 6th arch artery.
  •  This can lead to an increased risk of injury to the nerve during surgical procedures involving the thorax or neck.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 3rd pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries and the proximal part of the internal carotid arteries.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: It is not directly related to the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, its persistence or anomalies don't affect the recurrent laryngeal nerve's course.

 

Option B. 4th arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 4th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the left side into the arch of the aorta and on the right side into the right subclavian artery.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which arises from the vagus nerve, initially descends and then ascends around the 4th arch artery. However, this is not responsible for the long course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. 5th arch:

 

  • Derivative: Interestingly, in many cases, the 5th pharyngeal arch artery is rudimentary or even absent in humans. When present, it doesn't form any significant structures in the mature circulatory system.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: Given its rudimentary nature, the 5th arch artery doesn't have a defined relationship with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.

 

Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.

questions.text: Inhibitor A and B are: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive and non-competitive

 

Inhibitor A is a competitive inhibitor, and Inhibitor B is a non-competitive inhibitor.

 

  • Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor A): In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This means that increasing the concentration of the substrate can overcome the inhibition. In this scenario, the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the reaction remains unchanged because, at high substrate concentrations, the enzyme can still achieve its maximum rate. However, the apparent affinity of the enzyme for the substrate decreases, leading to an increase in the Michaelis constant (Km). On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the y-axis, which represents no change in Vmax but a change in Km.
  • Non-Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor B): Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an allosteric site rather than the active site, and their binding is not affected by the substrate concentration. As a result, the inhibition cannot be overcome by adding more substrate. Non-competitive inhibition leads to a decrease in the Vmax because the inhibitor reduces the overall number of active enzymes. However, Km remains unchanged because the binding of the inhibitor does not affect the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate. On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, non-competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the x-axis, reflecting no change in Km but a decrease in Vmax.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive and non-competitive: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This binding decreases both Km and Vmax because the inhibitor effectively removes some enzyme-substrate complexes from the reaction. This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A shows characteristics of competitive inhibition, not uncompetitive inhibition.

 

Option C. Non-competitive and uncompetitive: This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A is competitive, not non-competitive, and Inhibitor B is non-competitive, not uncompetitive. Therefore, this combination does not accurately represent the inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B.

 

Option D. Non-competitive and competitive: This option is incorrect because it reverses the correct inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B. Inhibitor A is competitive, while Inhibitor B is non-competitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember that competitive inhibitors increase Km but do not change Vmax, while non-competitive inhibitors decrease Vmax but do not change Km.

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Kata thermometer 

 

Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air. It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream. The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

 

Other Options

Option B. Globe Thermometer: Measures mean radiant temperature, which is the average temperature of all the surfaces surrounding a particular point. This is useful in assessing thermal comfort in environments.

 

Option C. Wet Globe Thermometer: Used to measure heat stress by taking into account temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. It is commonly used in the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT) index.

Option D. Dial Thermometer: Measures air temperature using a dial indicator. It is a general-purpose thermometer and not specifically designed for measuring air velocity.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with dysgerminoma of the ovary, which tumor marker is most likely to be elevated? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)

 

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary, accounting for 30-40% of malignant germ cell tumors. The characteristic tumor marker for dysgerminoma is Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH). This specific tumor marker is used clinically for diagnosis, monitoring treatment response, and surveillance for recurrence in patients with dysgerminoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Serum HCG: Serum HCG is the tumor marker for non-gestational choriocarcinoma of the ovary, not dysgerminoma. While some dysgerminomas may occasionally produce HCG if they contain syncytiotrophoblastic giant cells, it is not the primary or characteristic tumor marker for pure dysgerminoma.

 

Option B: Serum Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): Alpha-fetoprotein is the characteristic tumor marker for yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors). It is not typically elevated in pure dysgerminoma. If a dysgerminoma shows elevated AFP, it suggests the presence of mixed germ cell elements, particularly yolk sac components.

 

Option D: Serum CA 19-9: CA 19-9 is not a typical tumor marker for germ cell tumors of the ovary. It is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal malignancies, particularly pancreatic cancer. It may be elevated in some epithelial ovarian tumors, especially mucinous types, but not in dysgerminoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum LDH is the primary tumor marker for dysgerminoma and should be monitored for diagnosis, treatment response, and surveillance of this malignant germ cell tumor.

choices.text: Tissue factor

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Factor 2

 

Explanation

 

Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.

 

Factors II, VII, IX, X are vitamin k dependent coagulation factors, as their activated by carboxylation of their glutamate residues by enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K (reduced form) as a co-factor.

 

This reduced form of vitamin K is constantly oxidized for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Thus, warfarin affects vitamin k dependent factors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Factor 11: Incorrect, Factor XI is not vitamin K-dependent and thus not directly affected by warfarin therapy.

 

Option C. Tissue factor: Incorrect, Tissue factor (Factor III) is a different component of the clotting cascade that acts as a receptor and cofactor for Factor VIIa; it is not a vitamin K-dependent factor and is not affected by warfarin.

 

Option D. Factor 5: Incorrect, Factor V is not dependent on vitamin K for its function, so its activity is not diminished by warfarin therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin therapy impacts the function of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors by inhibiting the recycling of vitamin K, crucial for the carboxylation of these factors. Factor 2 (prothrombin) is one of these affected factors, leading to a reduction in its clotting ability in the presence of warfarin, which is utilized therapeutically to prevent thrombosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent bleeding for the past 1 year. Transnasal endoscopic results are shown below. A contrast-enhanced CT revealed a mass filling posterior choana to the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

The above clinical scenario with recurrent spontaneous bleeding with unilateral nasal obstruction and contrast-enhanced CT showing a growth protruding into the nasopharynx, along with the Transnasal endoscopic image, is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

 

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumor. It is predominantly seen in adolescent males and is thought to be testosterone-dependent. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity near the sphenopalatine foramen. 

 

Clinical features –

 

  • Epistaxis
  • Progressive nasal obstruction
  • Denasal speech
  • CHL
  • Broadening of nasal bridge
  • Proptosis leading to frog-face deformity
  • Involvement of cranial nerves – II, III, IV and VI

 

IOC is CECT – anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Millar sign)

 

Biopsy is avoided.

 

Treatment of choice – surgical approach

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antrochoanal Polyp: Typically arises from the maxillary sinus and extends into the choana, generally not as aggressive or vascular.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma: A chronic granulomatous condition caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the nasal passages and respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Concha Bullosa: An aerated turbinate that usually does not present with bleeding or significant obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Prompt and accurate diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is critical due to its potential for significant bleeding and local invasiveness. Treatment typically involves surgical removal, with preoperative planning crucial to manage the vascular nature of the tumor effectively.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. His HRCT thorax is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

 

In patients with HIV and respiratory failure, findings of GGO & cysts within GGO in perihilar locations on HRCT are characteristic for PCP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcal pneumonia: This typically presents with more localized consolidations or cavitary lesions rather than the diffuse, bilateral ground-glass opacities seen in PCP.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal pneumonia: Often manifests as lobar consolidation, which does not match the diffuse pattern observed in the HRCT.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: In HIV-positive patients, tuberculosis may present in various forms including miliary patterns or cavitary disease, especially if the CD4 count is low, but the diffuse ground-glass appearance is more characteristic of PCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Opportunistic Infection in HIV/Chap

questions.text: A 30-year-old female having a new sexual partner / boyfriend presented with painful ulcer on the vulva and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chancroid

 

The clinical presentation of a painful genital ulcer along with bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy strongly suggests chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

 

Chancroid:

 

  • Causative agent: Haemophilus ducreyi (Gram-negative coccobacillus).
  • Incubation period: 2-5 days after sexual exposure.
  • Genital ulcer characteristics:
    • Multiple, painful ulcers.

 

 

  • Irregular, soft edges (hence the term soft chancre).
  • Necrotic, yellow-gray base with purulent discharge.
  • Bleeds on touch.

 

Inguinal lymphadenopathy (Bubo):

 

  • Painful, unilateral or bilateral lymph nodes.

 

 

  • May progress to suppuration and rupture.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Clinical diagnosis is common.
  • Gram stain of ulcer exudate: "School of fish" or "railroad track" appearance.
  • Culture on Mueller-Hinton agar (low sensitivity).

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line therapy: Azithromycin (1 g single dose) or Ceftriaxone (250 mg IM single dose).
  • Alternative therapy: Erythromycin or Ciprofloxacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neisseria (Gonorrhea):

 

  • Causes purulent urethral or cervical discharge.
  • Does not cause genital ulcers.

 

Option C. Granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis):

 

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • Presents with a painless, beefy-red ulcer that bleeds easily.
  • No lymphadenopathy (pseudo-bubo may be seen).

 

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):

 

  • Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3 serovars).
  • Begins with a small, painless ulcer that heals spontaneously.
  • Followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (Bubo) associated with groove sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presenting as painful genital ulcers with inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is treated with Azithromycin or Ceftriaxone.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the lateral boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior epigastric vessels 

 

Hesselbach's triangle, also known as the inguinal triangle, is an anatomical area of the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

These vessels form the lateral border of the triangle. They run superomedially towards the umbilicus from the external iliac vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectus abdominis muscle: This is the medial border of Hesselbach's triangle.

 

Option B. Inguinal ligament: This forms the base or inferior border of the triangle. It is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Option D. Conjoint tendon: Also known as the inguinal aponeurotic falx, this is not a border of Hesselbach's triangle but is located just medial to the triangle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The inferior epigastric vessels form the lateral boundary of Hesselbach's triangle, which is an area of the abdominal wall clinically significant in the diagnosis of direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: A patient present with an X-ray showing cardiomegaly, along with symptoms of hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pompe's disease


Pompe's disease, also known as Type II glycogen storage disease, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (also known as alpha-glucosidase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen in the lysosomes. Without this enzyme, glycogen accumulates within the lysosomes, leading to lysosomal storage disease. The clinical features of Pompe's disease include cardiomegaly, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, macroglossia, and the characteristic "floppy baby" syndrome due to severe muscle weakness. The disease primarily affects the heart and skeletal muscles, often leading to heart failure as seen in the presented X-ray with cardiomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebstein anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect involving the tricuspid valve but does not present with hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, or the "floppy baby" syndrome seen in Pompe's disease. Ebstein anomaly primarily affects the heart, causing cyanosis and heart failure but lacks the systemic metabolic features of Pompe's.

 

Option C. Transposition of great arteries: This is another congenital heart defect characterized by the abnormal arrangement of the heart's major arteries. While it presents with severe cardiopulmonary symptoms such as cyanosis and heart failure, it does not cause hypotonia, macroglossia, or hepatomegaly, distinguishing it from Pompe's disease.

 

Option D.  Von Gierke's disease: Von Gierke's disease (Type I glycogen storage disease) affects liver metabolism, leading to severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, renomegaly, and metabolic derangements such as lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia. However, it does not involve cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, or "floppy baby" syndrome, making it an incorrect diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Pompe's disease is characterized by the combination of cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and macroglossia, often presenting as "floppy baby" syndrome due to lysosomal storage of glycogen.

questions.text: Under the National Cancer Control Programme, oncology wings were sanctioned to: [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Medical College Hospitals

 

  • The National Cancer Control Programme was launched in 1975-76 and revised in 1984-85 and 2004. Under the revised programme, the Oncology Wing Development Scheme was specifically initiated to fill geographic gaps in cancer treatment facilities. 
  • This scheme provides central assistance of Rs. 3 crores per institution for purchase of equipment (including cobalt units) and civil work, while the manpower is provided by the concerned state government/institution. 
  • Medical College Hospitals were prioritized for establishing these oncology wings to ensure wider accessibility of cancer treatment facilities across the country.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regional Cancer Centres: The Regional Cancer Centre Scheme is a separate component of the NCCP. Instead of establishing new oncology wings, this scheme focuses on strengthening existing regional cancer centers to act as referral centers for complicated cases at the tertiary level.

 

Option B. Private Hospitals: The NCCP does not sanction oncology wings to private hospitals. The programme primarily works through government healthcare infrastructure to ensure affordability and accessibility of cancer care.

 

Option D. Voluntary Organizations: Voluntary organizations are engaged under the "Decentralized NGO Scheme" component of NCCP, but specifically for IEC activities and early detection of cancer, not for establishing oncology wings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oncology Wing Development Scheme under NCCP strategically establishes cancer treatment facilities in Medical College Hospitals to address geographic gaps in cancer care availability while utilizing existing healthcare education infrastructure.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are conjugated to the steroid nucleus of bile acids? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycine and taurine

 

Bile acids are conjugated with glycine and taurine before being secreted into bile. Taurine is formed from cysteine through a series of reactions catalyzed by cysteine dioxygenase, sulfinoalanine decarboxylase, and hypotaurine dehydrogenase. Taurine can displace the coenzyme A moiety of cholyl-CoA to form the bile acid taurocholic acid. Similarly, glycine conjugation with bile acids occurs to form glycocholic acid. These conjugations increase the water solubility of bile acids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycine and alanine: While glycine is correctly identified as a bile acid conjugate, alanine does not participate in bile acid conjugation. Alanine primarily serves as a carrier of ammonia and pyruvate carbons from skeletal muscle to liver via the Cori cycle, but does not form conjugates with bile acids.

 

Option C. Histidine and glycine: Histidine is not involved in bile acid conjugation. Histidine is primarily involved in the formation of histamine through decarboxylation and participates in forming compounds like carnosine, homocarnosine, and anserine.

 

Option D. Glutamic acid and valine: Neither glutamic acid nor valine participates in bile acid conjugation. Glutamic acid is central to nitrogen metabolism, while valine is a branched-chain amino acid that undergoes specific catabolic pathways unrelated to bile acid chemistry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycine and taurine (derived from cysteine) are the two amino acids that conjugate with bile acids in the liver, increasing the water solubility of these compounds and facilitating their excretion into bile

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stress incontinence

 

Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by the involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during coughing, sneezing, or physical exertion. It is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse, where the support structures of the pelvic floor are weakened, leading to bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Overflow incontinence: Overflow incontinence occurs when the bladder cannot empty properly, leading to frequent or constant dribbling of urine. It is usually secondary to an obstruction, such as an enlarged prostate in men or severe prolapse in women causing a kink in the urethra. This condition does not typically present with leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure.

 

Option B. Urge incontinence: Urge incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine accompanied by or immediately preceded by a sudden, intense urge to urinate. This type of incontinence can be due to overactive bladder syndrome, where there is involuntary contraction of the bladder muscles.

 

Option D. Neurogenic bladder: Neurogenic bladder refers to a dysfunction of the urinary bladder due to a central or peripheral nervous system pathology. This can result in various types of incontinence, including both overflow and urge incontinence, depending on the nature of the neurological impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Ref: Page no 597, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heimlich’s maneuver

 

The image shows a Heimlich's maneuver

 

First aid for foreign body in the airway -

 

A large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.

 

The first aid measures consist of pounding on the back, turning the patient upside down and following Heimlich maneuver. These measures should not be done if the patient is only partially obstructed, for fear of causing total obstruction.

 

Heimlich maneuver. - Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Back Slaps: Before attempting the Heimlich maneuver, delivering five firm back slaps between the individual's shoulder blades can be tried as this may dislodge the item.

 

Option C. Chest Thrusts: Used instead of abdominal thrusts in cases where the Heimlich might be risky, such as in very obese or pregnant individuals.

 

Option D. Blind Finger Sweeps: Not recommended due to the risk of pushing the object deeper into the throat, potentially worsening the blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Heimlich maneuver is an effective emergency procedure for saving lives in cases of severe choking. It is important for everyone to learn this technique as it can be performed on others or even on oneself in a choking emergency.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 367

questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trophic ulcer

 

The image shows an ulcer on the sole of the foot with a characteristic appearance. It is surrounded by a white area due to callosities, indicating chronic pressure. This description is typical of a trophic ulcer, also known as a neuropathic ulcer. These ulcers occur in areas of the body subjected to prolonged pressure, often in patients with peripheral neuropathy. The lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and subsequent ulceration, which is commonly seen in the weight-bearing areas such as the soles of the feet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial ulcer: Arterial ulcers are typically located on the distal parts of the body such as the tips of toes and feet. They are often painful, with a "punched-out" appearance and a well-defined border. They usually have minimal exudate and occur due to inadequate blood supply.

 

Option B. Venous ulcer: Venous ulcers generally occur on the lower legs, particularly around the medial malleolus. They have irregular borders, are usually surrounded by hyperpigmentation, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. These ulcers are often exudative and less painful compared to arterial ulcers.

 

Option D. Diabetic ulcer: While diabetic ulcers can have a neuropathic component, they are a more complex condition with additional ischemic and infectious components. They are not exclusively located on pressure points and can appear anywhere on the foot. The distinguishing factor for trophic ulcers is their location on weight-bearing areas with surrounding callosities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophic (neuropathic) ulcers typically occur in weight-bearing areas, such as the soles of the feet, and are surrounded by callosities. They are primarily seen in patients with peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and ulceration. Recognizing this type of ulcer is crucial for appropriate management and prevention of further complications.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida is in labor. She has a repeated urge to pass urine and has premature bearing down. On examination there is infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart is heard on the lateral side. What is the most likely presentation/ position? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occipito-posterior

 

Explanation:

 

Occipito-posterior:

 

  • History:
    • Early rupture of membranes.
    • Frequent filling of bladder.
    • Premature bearing down.
  • Abdominal Examination:
    • Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus.
    • Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions.
    • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly.
  • Vaginal Examination:
    • An elongated bag of membranes.
    • The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint.
    • The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Brow: The brow presentation involves partial extension of the fetal head. The presenting diameter is larger, leading to a more difficult labor. However, this would not typically present with infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option B. Knee: A knee presentation is a form of breech presentation where the knees are the presenting part. It is rare and would not cause infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option D. Right dorso-anterior: This position involves the fetus's back being to the mother's right and anterior. It would not cause infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart sounds like the occipito-posterior position does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occipito-posterior position in labor is characterized by infra-umbilical flattening, frequent filling of the bladder, premature bearing down, and fetal heart sounds heard on the lateral side.

 

 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: Congested vessels cannot be moved with a cotton bud

questions.text: Which of the following is indicative of episcleritis rather than scleritis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine

 

Blanching of vessels with 10% phenylephrine is characteristic of episcleritis and helps differentiate it from scleritis. This occurs because:

 

  • In episcleritis, the inflammation affects the episcleral vessels which are superficial
  • These superficial vessels constrict in response to topical vasoconstrictors like phenylephrine
  • This vasoconstrictive response results in blanching of the redness
  • The deeper vessels involved in scleritis are not affected by topical vasoconstrictors

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Severe Pain:

 

  • Severe pain is characteristic of scleritis, not episcleritis
  • Episcleritis typically causes mild discomfort or irritation
  • Scleritis pain is often described as deep, boring, and may wake the patient at night
  • The pain in scleritis may radiate to the temple and forehead

 

Options B. Tenderness:

 

  • Marked tenderness on palpation is typical of scleritis
  • Episcleritis shows minimal or no tenderness
  • The tenderness in scleritis corresponds to the area of inflammation
  • This tenderness is due to deeper inflammation affecting scleral tissue

 

Options C. Congested vessels cannot be moved with a cotton bud:

 

  • Immobile vessels are characteristic of scleritis
  • In episcleritis, the vessels are superficial and can be moved with a cotton bud
  • The immobility in scleritis occurs because the inflammation is within the scleral tissue
  • This is a useful clinical test to differentiate between the two conditions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blanching of vessels with vasoconstrictors like phenylephrine is a key diagnostic feature of episcleritis, distinguishing it from scleritis which shows no blanching due to deeper vessel involvement.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

 

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

 

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

 

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome.

 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Culex: This genus of mosquitoes is not a known vector for Zika virus but is commonly associated with the transmission of the West Nile virus.

 

Option C. Anopheles: Known primarily for transmitting malaria, not Zika virus.

 

Option D. Phlebotomus papatasii: These are sandflies and known vectors for the virus causing leishmaniasis, not Zika.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parainfluenza

 

Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

 

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

 

Management:

 

  • ﻿﻿Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction.
  • Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • ﻿﻿Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>|V>|M). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • ﻿﻿Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (Sp02 <92 %)

 

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moraxella: More commonly associated with conditions like otitis media and sinusitis rather than croup.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Although capable of causing respiratory tract infections, it is not a typical cause of croup.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Known for more severe respiratory conditions like bacterial tracheitis, which is distinct from viral croup and presents with more severe symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parainfluenza is a common cause of croup. The 'Steeple sign' on X-ray supports this diagnosis, emphasizing the need for prompt and effective treatment to ensure rapid recovery and prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following Vibrio species is most commonly linked to ear infections? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Vibrio alginolyticus

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio alginolyticus is the Vibrio species most commonly linked to ear infections. This halophilic (salt-loving) Vibrio is the most salt-tolerant of the species, capable of growing at salt concentrations greater than 10%. V. alginolyticus is specifically associated with eye and ear infections, including otitis externa and otitis media. These infections typically occur after exposure to seawater, making this organism a significant concern for swimmers and those engaged in water activities in marine environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vibrio parahaemolyticus - This species primarily causes food-borne gastroenteritis following consumption of undercooked seafood, particularly oysters. While it can occasionally cause otitis and wound infections as extraintestinal manifestations, it is not the Vibrio species most commonly associated with ear infections.

 

Option C. Vibrio vulnificus - This species is known for causing severe, potentially fatal infections, particularly in individuals with liver disease or immunocompromised states. It primarily causes primary sepsis in high-risk individuals and wound infections. V. vulnificus is notable for being the only Vibrio that ferments lactose, but it is not typically associated with ear infections.

 

Option D. Vibrio fluvialis - This is a less common Vibrio species that can cause gastroenteritis. It is not particularly associated with ear infections compared to V. alginolyticus, which has a strong association with otitis externa and otitis media.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vibrio alginolyticus is the most salt-tolerant Vibrio species and has a particular tropism for causing eye and ear infections (otitis externa and otitis media), making it an important pathogen to consider in patients with ear infections following exposure to seawater.

questions.text: Drug of choice for malaria (plasmodium vivax) in pregnancy? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

 

The treatment of malaria in pregnancy, especially caused by Plasmodium vivax, requires special consideration due to the potential effects on both the mother and the fetus. The key points are:

 

  • Chloroquine: Chloroquine is the drug of choice for treating Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnant women. It is effective and safe during pregnancy.
  • Alternative Drugs: If there is resistance to chloroquine, quinine can be used as a secondary option.
  • For Plasmodium falciparum malaria, artesunate is the preferred drug, followed by quinine, both of which can be safely used during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine + Primaquine: This combination is not used in pregnancy due to the contraindication of primaquine. Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause hemolytic anemia in the fetus, especially in those with G6PD deficiency. It is not used for radical cure in pregnant women and is deferred until after delivery.

 

Option C. Quinine: While quinine can be used if there is resistance to chloroquine, it is not the first-line treatment for Plasmodium vivax.

 

Option D. Artesunate: Artesunate is the drug of choice for Plasmodium falciparum malaria but not for Plasmodium vivax in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy

 

  • Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days.
  • To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery.
  • For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over.
  • Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision.
  • Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion.
  • Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia.
  • Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable.
  • Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.

questions.text: In a class trip there were 75 camper school students, of which 50 had been immunized for Measles previously. During the trip, a child developed Measles. Subsequently, upon returning home, 12 more children developed Measles. Calculate the Secondary attack rate for Measles. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50%

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is calculated using the formula: 


SAR 

 

 

  • Total students = 75
  • Previously immunized = 50 (these are immune and not susceptible)
  • Susceptible students initially = 75 - 50 = 25
  • One student developed measles first (primary case)
  • Therefore, remaining susceptibles = 24
  • Secondary cases = 12

 

Applying the formula: SAR = (12/24) × 100 = 50%

 

The primary case is excluded both from numerator and denominator as they cannot be a secondary case.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR) is the number of cases occurring within the incubation period following exposure to a primary case, expressed as a percentage of the total number of exposed susceptible persons. The primary case should be excluded from both numerator and denominator.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that has not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa with consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to form histamine.

 

Symptoms develop within 15-90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. The more severe and commonly described presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8-12 h.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Salmonella: Incorrect because Salmonella is not typically involved in the histamine production leading to scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus: Incorrect as Staphylococcus does not contribute to histamine production in fish, which is the primary cause of scombroid poisoning.

 

Option D. Peptostreptococcus: Incorrect because Peptostreptococcus is not associated with the decomposition of fish that leads to histamine production and subsequent scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Educational Objective

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is primarily caused by the decarboxylation of L-histidine into histamine by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa in improperly stored fish, leading to a range of symptoms from mild gastrointestinal discomfort to severe allergic reactions.

questions.text: Identify the structure pointed in the anatomical snuffbox. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Option C) 

 

  • The marked muscle in the anatomical snuffbox is the extensor pollicis longus. 
  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is a long muscle located at the deep layer with extensor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, and supinator muscle in the posterior compartment of the forearm. 
  • It originates from the mid-third of the ulna, and interosseous membrane then courses down to the distal phalanx of the thumb. 
  • Though it is situated at the forearm, but it is classified as part of the extrinsic muscles of the hand as its function is seen in thumb movement.

 

ANATOMICAL SNUFFBOX

 

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the dorsum of the hand. 
  • It is formed by three tendons of the muscles of the thumb i.e., abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus. 
  • It is a clinically significant area due to the structures it contains, including the radial artery and the scaphoid bone. 
  • Components of anatomical snuffbox are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus (APL) is one of the extrinsic muscles of the hand. Its major function is to abduct the thumb at the wrist. Its tendon forms the anterior border of the anatomical snuffbox.

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) belongs to the deep group of the posterior fascial compartment of the forearm. It is a part of the lateral border of the anatomical snuffbox. This muscle extends the thumb at the MCP and CMC joints. It is also a mild abductor of the thumb.

 

 

Option D. Cephalic vein: The cephalic vein arises as a convergence of superficial veins on the dorsum of the hand in the anatomical snuffbox. From there it runs along the surface just above the radial styloid process. Just beneath the clavicle, the cephalic vein drains into the axillary vein, which bends downwards towards the heart.

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

  • The marked muscle tendon the given image is of the extensor pollicis longus in the anatomical snuffbox. 
  • It forms the medial boundary of the snuffbox and functions to extend the thumb.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lecithin

 

Newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome which is due to surfactant deficiency, i.e., lecithin.

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Hyaline Membrane Disease)

 

 

The newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, which is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and maintaining proper lung function. Lecithin, also known as dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC), is the most important component of surfactant. A deficiency in lecithin leads to insufficient surfactant production, resulting in alveolar collapse, reduced functional residual capacity (FRC), and the clinical features observed in RDS.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Dipalmitoyl inositol: This is not a component of surfactant. The main components of surfactant are phospholipids like lecithin and other proteins.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While present in amniotic fluid and used in the lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio to assess fetal lung maturity, it is not the primary component of surfactant.

 

Option D. Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylethanolamine: This is a phospholipid but not a primary component of surfactant involved in preventing alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign is characteristic of:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simple bone cyst

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Also known as unicameral bone cyst.
  • It affects children in the first and second decade.
  • The lesions are most active during skeletal growth and usually heal spontaneously at maturity.
  • They arise in the metaphysis and are central or medullary.
  • The proximal humerus and proximal femur are common sites.
  • It is not a tumor.
  • The condition is usually asymptomatic, unless discovered after a pathological fracture or as an incidental finding on X-ray.
  • An SBC contains serous or serosanguinous fluid.
  • Plain radiographs reveal a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline.
  • Occasionally (20%), a thinned cortical fragment fractures and falls into the base of the lesion confirming its empty cystic nature. This, ‘Fallen Fragment’ sign, is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst.
  • Bone fragment may also hinge around and move with fluid – ‘Trap Door sign’
  • Unicameral bone cysts are classified as active when they are within 1 cm of the physis and latent when they are closer to the diaphysis.
  • Small, asymptomatic lesions in the upper extremities can be treated with observation with serial plain radiographs.
  • Larger lesions (lesions at risk for pathological fracture), symptomatic lesions, and lesions in the lower extremities are usually are treated with curettage (with or without bone grafting or internal fixation) or aspiration and injection (often using steroids, bone marrow aspirate, demineralized bone matrix, or sclerosant).

 

 

A. Unicameral or simple bone cyst; B. Fallen fragment (leaf) sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aneurysmal bone cyst. Aneurysmal bone cysts are locally destructive, blood-filled reactive lesions of bone and are not considered to be true neoplasms. Most commonly involves the lower limbs. Vertebral lesions (15-20%) are located in the posterior elements.

 

 

Radiographs reveal an expansile lytic lesion that elevates the periosteum, but remains contained by a thin shell of cortical bone. It can have well-defined margins or a permeative appearance that mimics a malignancy. It is most often eccentrically located in the metaphysis. When differentiating between a unicameral and aneurysmal bone cyst using MRI, the presence of a double-density fluid level and intralesional septations usually indicates an aneurysmal bone cyst.

 

 

Double-density fluid level on MRI

 

Aneurysmal bone cysts are treated with extended curettage and grafting. Lesions in the spine or pelvis can be treated with preoperative embolization to minimize surgical blood loss. Low-dose irradiation is an effective method of treatment, often associated with rapid ossification; however, it is not used routinely because of the potential for malignant transformation.

 

Option C. Giant cell tumor. They typically occur in 20-40 years old patients. There is a slight female predominance. The most common location is the distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone. Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.

 

 

Treatment includes extended curettage and bone grafting; excision and replacement by vascularized bone graft/prosthetic replacement.

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fallen fragment sign is seen in simple (unicameral) bone cyst. It is a thinned cortical fragment that fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature

questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) III

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates Type 3 placenta previa where the placenta partially covers the internal os. This classification is part of the older classification system known as Browne’s classification.

 

Placenta previa is categorized into different types based on how much the placenta covers the internal os of the cervix:

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification):

 

  • Type 1: The lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os.
  • Type 2: The placenta reaches the margin of the os but doesn’t cover it.
  • Type 3: The placenta partially covers the internal os (when fully dilated, it doesn’t cover).
  • Type 4: The placenta completely covers the os.

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography - TVS; by ACOG):

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: The placenta covers the internal os.
  2. Low-lying Placenta: The placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV: This would mean the placenta completely covers the os, which is not the case in the given image.

 

Option C. II: This would mean the placenta reaches the margin of the os but does not cover it, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. I: This would mean the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os, which does not align with the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is classified based on the extent to which the placenta covers the internal os, with Type 3 indicating partial coverage.

 

Types of Placentae previa

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification)

 

 

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography -TVS); By ACOG

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: Placenta covers the internal os
  2. Low lying placenta: Placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it. 

 

Ref: Page 658, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the test of significance conducted for two or more proportions? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used to determine if there is a significant association between categorical variables. It is especially useful for testing the relationship between two or more proportions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Student's test: This typically refers to the t-test, which is used to compare means between two groups. It is not appropriate for proportions.

 

Option C. Z test: While the Z test can be used for proportions, it is usually employed for large sample sizes and comparing the means of two populations.

 

Option D. ANOVA: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is used to compare the means among three or more groups, not for comparing proportions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use has developed confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for this presentation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B1

 

The patient's presentation of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, along with a history of chronic alcohol use, is indicative of a deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine). This clinical picture is consistent with Wernicke's Encephalopathy, a serious neurological disorder most commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Alcohol use can lead to poor dietary intake and absorption, contributing to thiamine deficiency.
