Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the triad of mental confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency in Vitamin B2 can lead to symptoms like skin disorders, anemia, and sore throat, but it is not typically associated with the neurological symptoms described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): While Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, they are typically peripheral neuropathies or seizures, not the classic triad seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Deficiency in Vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and poor wound healing, which are not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with chronic alcohol use presenting with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, a Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency leading to Wernicke's Encephalopathy should be considered.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: A patient with the respiratory difficulty and had a history of Chronic smoking. His pulmonary function testing showed decrease FEV1 %. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) COPD

 

Explanation: 

 

This case presents a classic presentation of COPD with several key diagnostic features:

 

  • History of smoking (major risk factor)
  • Progressive dyspnea and chronic cough (typical symptoms)
  • PFT findings showing: 
    • Decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio <70% (diagnostic criteria for airflow obstruction/Obstructive disease)
    • Fixed obstruction with minimal bronchodilator response(distinguishes from asthma very good improvement in FEV1) .
    • According to GOLD criteria, post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% confirms the presence of persistent airflow limitation and COPD diagnosis in patients with appropriate symptoms and risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary fibrosis: Incorrect because pulmonary fibrosis shows a restrictive pattern on PFTs with FEV1/FVC ratio >70% and reduced total lung capacity, not an obstructive pattern as seen here.

 

Option C. Interstitial lung disease (ILD): Incorrect because like pulmonary fibrosis, ILD demonstrates a restrictive pattern on PFTs, not obstruction. ILD would show decreased lung volumes with preserved FEV1/FVC ratio.

 

Option D. Asthma: Incorrect because although asthma can show decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio, it typically demonstrates significant bronchodilator reversibility (>12% and >200mL improvement in FEV1), which is not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic criteria for COPD: post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <70% with minimal bronchodilator response in a patient with risk factors and appropriate symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoea

 

The history of multiple sexual partners and lower abdominal pain with discharge and intermenstrual bleed suggests a diagnosis of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, of which cause can be N. Gonorrhoea among the given options.

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

 

 

Treatment –

 

KIT 6 (Yellow) – Tab Cefixime 400mg 1 Tab

 

  • Tab Metronidazole 400 mg (1 tab BD x 1 days)
  •  Tab Doxycycline 100 mg (1 tab BD x 21 days)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex causes painful genital ulcers.

 

Option B. Genital tuberculosis: Genital tuberculosis is seen in sexually inactive females

 

Option C. Vaginal candidiasis: Vaginal candidiasis presents as intense pruritus and white discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is most commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections, with Neisseria gonorrhoeae being a major pathogen, especially in women with multiple sexual partners presenting with lower abdominal pain and intermenstrual bleeding.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test of choice for HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV DNA PCR
 

Maternal antibodies transferred passively to the infant may persist 9-18 months and hence ELISA/antibody tests positivity would indicate possible exposure to HIV.

 

Currently NACO recommends HIV-TNA PCR (Total nucleic acid = pro-viral DNA + RNA) which has Sensitivity of 99% and Specificity of 98% in infants < 18 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DBS (Dried blood sample) is recommended and not CORD BLOOD (as it contains maternal blood contamination).

 

Option C. Western blot is not recommended by NACO for the diagnosis of HIV.

 

Option D. ELISA based test detects antibodies, however, maternal transmission occurs in infants trans placentally and hence cannot help in diagnosis of active disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants born to HIV-infected mothers, HIV DNA PCR is the preferred diagnostic test because it detects viral DNA directly, avoiding the pitfalls of tests that detect antibodies, which may not distinguish between maternal antibodies and those produced by the infant itself.

 

Reference: NACO 2021 HIV Care and treatment guidelines Page 185

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with painful genital ulcers along with painful inguinal buboes. He had a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

The patient's symptoms of painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) are characteristic of Chancroid. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and typically presents with painful ulcers on the genitals and tender, often pus-filled lymph nodes (buboes) in the groin.

 

When differentiating between sexually transmitted infections that cause genital ulcers, it is important to note whether the ulcers are painful or painless:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LGV (Lymphogranuloma Venereum): Incorrect because the genital ulcers in LGV are typically painless and transient. Although buboes are seen in LGV, the painful ulcers in this case suggest another diagnosis.

 

Option C. Herpes genitalis: Incorrect because, although Herpes genitalis presents with painful ulcers, it usually does not involve painful inguinal buboes. Additionally, a history of recurrence might be mentioned, which is absent here.

 

Option D. Chancre (Syphilis): Incorrect because the ulcer in syphilis (chancre) is typically painless, and the lymphadenopathy is also painless.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid should be suspected in a patient with painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), especially in the absence of a history of recurrence and when syphilis and LGV have been ruled out based on the clinical presentation.

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can mimic erythroblastosis fetalis due to its ability to infect erythroid progenitor cells and inhibit erythropoiesis, leading to severe anemia. Erythroblastosis fetalis typically results from maternal antibodies targeting fetal red blood cells, causing hemolysis and severe anemia; Parvovirus B19 causes a similar effect through a direct infection of the erythroid cells.

 

Parvovirus B19 is associated with:

 

  1. Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)
  2. Transient aplastic crisis
  3. Pure red cell aplasia
  4. Erythroblastosis fetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy)

 

Erythema infectiosum rash :

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): Incorrect, as HSV does not typically cause the hematologic manifestations associated with erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): Incorrect, while EBV can cause hematological disturbances, it does not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis but is more associated with conditions like infectious mononucleosis.

 

Option C. Picornavirus: Incorrect, this group of viruses, which includes enteroviruses and rhinoviruses, does not produce hematological symptoms that mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can uniquely mimic erythroblastosis fetalis by causing severe fetal anemia and related complications through its direct impact on erythroid progenitor cells. Awareness of this potential complication is essential, particularly in pregnant women, as the infection can lead to significant fetal outcomes, necessitating careful monitoring and management.

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point V to point X as shown below. Which of the following happens in stage W compared to stage Y?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Shivering

 

Explanation:

 

In the above scenario, the patient's hypothalamic thermostat has been reset to a higher temperature, hence the body uses methods like shivering to increase the temperature.

 

 

 

Fig: Effects changing the set-point of the hypothalamic temperature

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sweating

 

  • Stage W: Sweating is unlikely in this phase because the body is in the process of heating up to meet the new higher set point. Sweating is a mechanism used to reduce body temperature and would be counterproductive at this stage.
  • Stage Y: Sweating becomes prominent here as the body seeks to dissipate excess heat after reaching or surpassing the set point.

 

Option C. Increased blood flow to the skin

 

  • Stage W: There is typically decreased blood flow to the skin during this phase due to vasoconstriction, which helps to retain heat. Increasing blood flow to the skin would be counterproductive as it would lead to increased heat loss.
  • Stage Y: Increased blood flow to the skin occurs in this phase to facilitate heat loss through the skin, aiding in thermoregulation by cooling the body down.

 

Option D. Inhibition of chemical thermogenesis

 

  • Stage W: There is actually an increase in chemical thermogenesis during this stage. Chemical thermogenesis, including actions such as the metabolic effects of shivering and brown fat activation, helps to generate additional heat.
  • Stage Y: As the body temperature stabilizes or exceeds the set point, there might be a natural reduction in chemical thermogenesis as the need to generate heat reduces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TEMPERATURE REGULATION -

questions.text: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum is most commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Reactive Arthritis

 

Explanation: 

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum is a characteristic skin manifestation associated with reactive arthritis. Reactive arthritis is part of the "PAIR" group of conditions associated with HLA-B27. Reactive arthritis typically follows an infection, particularly those caused by certain bacteria like Chlamydia or enteric pathogens. The condition is characterized by the classic triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, with keratoderma blennorrhagicum being a distinctive skin lesion that can appear on the palms and soles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis - This is an autoimmune disease associated with HLA-DR4, not HLA-B27. Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints but doesn't feature keratoderma blennorrhagicum.

 

Option B. Psoriatic Arthritis - While psoriatic arthritis is part of the HLA-B27 associated group (PAIR), keratoderma blennorrhagicum is not a typical manifestation. Psoriatic arthritis is associated with psoriatic skin lesions, not keratoderma blennorrhagicum.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis - Although ankylosing spondylitis is also part of the HLA-B27 associated group (PAIR), it primarily affects the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints) and doesn't typically present with keratoderma blennorrhagicum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum is a characteristic skin manifestation of reactive arthritis, which is part of the HLA-B27 associated spondyloarthropathies (PAIR: Psoriatic arthritis, Ankylosing spondylitis, IBD-associated arthritis, and Reactive arthritis).

choices.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.
Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine. Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss. These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non vertebral fractures.
  • Prolonged used of Bisphosphonates has been reported with increased incidence of fractures of proximal femur. Hence, a patient on Bisphosphonates with hip pain requires X-rays to evaluate and diagnose these fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time. Teriparatide is a recombinant fragment of human parathyroid hormone. To preserve the increments of BMD acquired with teriparatide, therapy with an antiresorptive agent (e.g., bisphosphonates) should restart after teriparatide discontinuation. Bisphosphonates help retain BMD gains that tend to regress after cessation of teriparatide. Concomitant use with teriparatide is to be avoided because they may blunt its anabolic effect.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day. 1200 mg of calcium (total of diet and supplement) and 800 international units of vitamin D daily for postmenopausal osteoporosis are recommended.

 

Option D. Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation is a necessary adjunct to all forms of anti-osteoporotic therapies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.
